conclusion: With no current, the rod is at rest and the only forces acting on it are its weight mg (downward) and the tensions of the two identical suspension wires (upward).
Because the rod is in equilibrium, the total upward force equals the weight: 2T₀ = mg ⟹ T₀ = mg/2, where T₀ is the tension in one wire in the 'no-current' case.
After the current I is switched on, the tension in each wire falls to one-quarter of its former value.
T₁ = T₀ /4 = (mg/2)/4 = mg/8. Hence the two wires now provide an upward support force of 2T₁ = mg/4.
Besides the tensions and the weight, the rod experiences a magnetic force F = IBL, whose direction is perpendicular to both the current and the magnetic field.
The rod is still at rest, so the vertical forces satisfy upward forces = downward forces: 2T₁ + F = mg.
Insert 2T₁ = mg/4: mg/4 + F = mg ⟹ F = mg − mg/4 = 3mg/4.
The magnetic force on a straight conductor of length L in a field B that is perpendicular to the conductor is F = IBL.
The field is into the page (× symbols).
To obtain an upward magnetic force (needed to reduce the wire tension), the current must flow to the left (N → M).
Using the right-hand rule: fingers along current, palm pushed in the direction of B (into page), thumb then points upward.
Magnitude of the current: I = 3mg /(4BL), Direction: from end N to end M (i.e. right-to-left in the diagram).
